body.head: Before you begin...
body.p: In this exercise you will be using a few of the many tools available for creating and processing TEI XML files. We'll mostly be using the XML editor Oxygen, which should be installed on your work stations already: you can start it up by just clicking on the Oxygen XML Editor icon on the desktop, or selecting it from the Programs menu in the usual way.

You'll also need some sample files to work with. We've provided all of these in a zip file, which you can download from http://bit.ly/Nj0yce. Before you begin, please download this zip file to your desktop, and click on it to unpack. This should give you a folder called Practical containing everything you will need, notably a copy of this tutorial.

In two hours we can't do more than sketch some of the things that markup makes possible. But we hope to give you some idea about the following topics:
creating a TEI XML document from scratch : the born digital document
using a customised TEI schema to mark up plain text and Word files
the range of markup possible
using markup to retrieve and display from a set of documents

div.head: The born-digital document
div.p:
Oxygen makes it easy to
create a born digital XML document
add XML tags to a document
continously validate the document against a simple schema
display the document in various ways

Oxygen can be configured for use in several languages, including English, French, German, and Italian. If you'd prefer to work in some language other than English, use the Preferences command, the first option on the Options menu (fifth from left on the menu bar), to change it. This tutorial mostly assumes you are using the English version, though some of the illustrations are taken from the French version, and so may not match exactly what you see on the screen.

div.head: TEI a la carte : customization
div.p: In the rest of this session, we'll see how TEI markup might be used in an imaginary (but quite plausible) research project. We'll discuss what markup scheme the project will need, create a TEI schema to support it, and do some experimental markup using it.

As you probably don't know, the late Marcel Virgolos has long been recognised as an expert on the history and evolution of the 20th century postcard. Following his untimely demise, we have received permission from his executors to create a digital research archive of some parts of his unique personal collection of 100,000 mostly used postcards of all kinds in order to further the progress of serious cartophilological studies. We've put digital images of a tiny sample from the collection in the folder Cards inside your Practical folder.

div.head: Sample text
div.p: In this part of the exercise we will markup one postcard, respecting its organization into recto and verso, and the components of its address, etc. To make your life easier, we have prepared a transcription already for you, so you don't need to do quite so much typing as in the previous exercise...
Here's the recto of the card :
And here's the verso :

Of course the first part of our research project was spent arguing about how to markup these documents, and if we had more time we'd rerun some of that discussion now. We used a TEI tool called Roma to create an appropriate subset of our needs, expressed as a schema called virgolos in honour of our cher maître.

div.head: Create a new document
div.p: As before, open Oxygen and click on the New icon at top left to open the New document dialogue. This time, when asked to choose which document type to use, select XML Document from the New Document section. Then click on the Customize button at the bottom of the dialog box, to open the Customize Editor dialog box. At the far right of the box labelled Schema URL there is a small triangle which you can click to open a drop down menu. Select Browse for local file, and navigate to the file virgolos.rnc in the Practical folder. Press the Create button at the bottom. We will use this schema, which is rather less minimalist than the one we used in the first exercise.

list.item: As before, Oxygen gives you the basic TEI structure, with a few extra components.

Complete the TEI header just as you did before. We suggest the following as title The Bathing Beach, Brighton, 1846 : digital edition of card 19701026_0004 from the Virgolos collection. For the publication statement, something like Unpublished sample, produced as part of the DH Summer School Oxford 2012 would be fine.
For the source description, if you like, you could include all the bibliographic information from the verso of the card, like this:

div.head: Adding text to the document
div.p:
You can, of course, make your own transcription But this time we propose the following method:
Check that your cursor is between the <body> and </body> tags in your empty document
Choose Document -> File -> Insert File from the menu bar (Not the File Menu on the menu bar, but the one on the Document Menu)
Navigate to the file card-0004.txt which you will find in the Cards folder , select it, and click Open.
Your document is full of red lines but don't panic! we will sort that out in a moment. Look at the error message at the foot of the screen and see if you understand it.

div.head: Adding structure to the body of a document
div.p:
The structure of a document is important. As we discussed earlier, every card, including this one, has
two divisions ... to be tagged with <div type="recto"> and <div type="verso"> respectively
inside the verso (in this case) there is a further division : one part contains the message, and the other contains an address and other information about the destination of the card, such as the postmark, postage stamp etc.
Our markup should distinguish all these things. Note that we think this approach will be more useful than simply mimicking the physical layout of the card -- we have a picture of it, after all. Let's go !

list.item: Select all the text you just added

Type CTRL-E and choose div from the list of available tags ; our schema requires you also to specify what kind of division this, using the type attribute. Choose "recto" from the drop down list and then click Accept
Put the cursor after the word 1846 and use SHIFT-ALT-D or some other way of splitting the division as you did in the previous exercise.
The bit of text "Beach view...and mats" describes the graphic. The tag for this is figDesc. Select that stretch of texts, type CTRL-E and wrap a figDesc round it.
The bit of text "The Bathing ... 1846" is the caption of a graphic. The tag for this is head. Select that stretch of texts, type CTRL-E and wrap a head round it.

The three elements you've now marked up (graphic figDesc head) together form a figure. Select all three of them and wrap a figure round them. The red lines at the start of your text should now all have gone. Onward!

div.p: Now for the verso ... The plain text mixes up transcription of things written on the card and brief notes describing various kinds of stamp added to it, in a rather confusing way. Our markup will sort that out. Our aim is to separate the division containing the verso into two subdivisions : one (of type message) containing the transcribed message, and the other (of type destinationcontaining all the information about the sending of it -- the address, the stamps, etc. We will use the p element for paragraphs of transcribed text, and within that stamp for the various kinds of stamp. We will also mark up the various components of the address.

Before we begin, however, we have to decide what to do with the graphic. We hope you agree that there is a difference between the status of the graphic for the recto and that for the verso. We treated the recto as a figure within our digital version, but the verso is something parallel to the transcription, not part of it, in the way that (if we had them) digital images of the stamps might be. Hence our suggestion below. But you should feel free to experiment with other approaches or argue about the topic.
Change the value recto inside the the div tag at the start of the verso into verso. Type a space. A list of other available attributes appears.
Choose facs from the list. Its value should be the string 197001026_004v.jpg, which is currently the value for the url attribute on the existing graphic element. Cut and paste this string into the right place, and then delete the rest of the graphic element : we don't need it.
Now select the whole of the text (i.e. from "You" to "OXFORD") and type CTRL-E to surround it with a single p.
While you're there, wrap another div element round the whole thing too. Inside the start-tag for divtype a space, and select type from the list of attributes available. Press return and you will see what values are predefined for this attribute: choose message.
Almost all the red lines disappear : can you see why we still have a couple associated with those ampersands? The error message at the bottom of the screen may help.
That's right : there are just a couple of characters which are magic inside an XML document, and hence need to be treated specially. The pointy bracket is one (for obvious reasons) and the ampersand is another. Just replace the ampersands with the sequence &, so that it now reads Brighton & Hove
The little green square reappears ! Have we finished? Sorry, no : a document can be valid while still containing many lies ... and lies can also be dangerous : to see why, hit the Indentation button on the toolbar (or type CTRL-SHIFT-P).

Since the line endings are not explicit in the markup, Oxygen is not obliged to respect them when formatting the display. To be both honest and explicit, we need to separate the paragraphs in the message from each other and the signature, and we also need to separate the descriptive text about the stamps from the transcribed text.

list.item: Bring back the original display by typing CTRL-Z.
Split the one paragraph into several, by pressing SHIFT-ALT-D with the cursor positioned after the words is, Fitzherbert, Mama, and vermilion

Now put the cursor between the end of the paragraph containing the word Mama and the start of the next paragraph, i.e. between the

and the

. Type SHIFT-ALT-D to split the inner division.

Now that we have separated the message out as a separate division, it's possible to mark up some of its internal features. The word Mama isn't part of the message -- it's a signature, for which the element signed is provided. You can fix this just by retyping the tags, or, if you prefer, put the cursor inside the p start-tag, and select Document - XML refactoring - Rename element (ALT-SHIFT-R). Then choose signed from the list of available elements and press Return.
The remaining div contains three stamp descriptions and an address: according to our schema, its type value should be destination : make it so.

Now tag each of the three stamp-descriptions with the stamp element (we leave it to you whether you do that by making a single stamp element and splitting it, or by selecting each description and enclosing it with CTRL-E)

Lastly, let's deal with the addressee. Select the whole of the address text and (using CTRL-E) tag it as address. Red line reappears! That's because the components of an address must be distinguished : you cannot have just plain text inside this tag. You could markup those components of the address which are names (using name) and those which make up a street address (using street); or you could just tag each line of the address separately using addrLine. You could even do both (put the names etc. inside the address lines, if you do)... As is often the way in the TEI, it's Up To You.

div.head: Reality check
div.p: As you've already seen, Oxygen can display the hierarchic structure of the document -- if you look in the Summary window to the left and expand some of the buttons there you should now see something like this :
Have we finished our markup now?

Clearly there is no simple answer to this question. We've marked up the basic structure of the document in such a way that we can identify and display its components in various ways (we'll see some of those later). But we haven't marked up everything possible within that structure. We'll come back to this point at the end of the exercise.

div.head: Importing from Word
div.p: You've seen how to make a valid TEI document out of nothing at all, and out of a plain text file. In reality, many documents start life in a word processor such as Word or Open Office. Can we work with those too?

In the Cards folder you have a small Word document called Les deux soeurs.docx. This contains a nicely formatted transcription of a third postcard. You may like to open it using Word, just to check that it is in fact a Word document, with nice formatting and no sign of any pointy brackets.
How can we convert this document into TEI-XML?

We could save it in plain text format and use that ; we could cut and paste the text into Oxygen. But either method would be tiresome and would also lose information, such as underlining or changes of font size.

Since this Word file uses formatting in a consistent way, using Word styles, it's possible to transform it to XML more or less automatically, losing very little information. Oxygen can be configured to do this for you, but we will use a different tool for a change.

list.item: Open your Internet browser (use Chrome if this is available), and visit http://www.tei-c.org/ege-webclient/
Click Text Documents. In the list of different formats proposed, check the radio button for Microsoft Word Document(.docx)
A list of target formats appears to the right. Check the radio button for TEI P5 XML.
At the top of the screen a Choose File button appears. Click on this and navigate to the file Les deux soeurs.docx in your Cards folder.
Click the big Convert button ... be patient

The Garage will send you (after a brief delay) an archive called Les deux soeurs.zip. (Note that if you are using Internet Explorer, you may have to reassure the software that you really do want to download this dangerous file)

Find this zip archive in your Downloads folder, or wherever it is, and click on it to unpack. You should find that it contains a folder called Media and a file called tei.xml. This is the XML version of the file.

div.head: Tag translating
div.p: Let's see what OxGarage has made out of our Word file. At least it's a valid TEI document, even if it is full of lies...

list.item: Start up Oxygen, and open the file tei.xml which you just created.

div.p: Don't look at the TEI Header for the moment : you can complete that later. If you look at the summary view, or change briefly to Author mode, you will see that the conversion has been able to distinguish the three main components of the verso of the card -- the message, the stamps, and the address -- because they were formatted differently in the Word file. This makes our life much easier.
Starting at the end, we can see that the address has been turned into a table, in which each row contains a single cell containing one line of the address.

list.item: In Text view, put the cursor insideany one of the cell elements
From the Document menu choose the XML-Refactoring -> Rename Element command (or type ALT-SHIFT-R).
In the New name box, change cell to addrLine, which is the name of the element we want, and check the box Rename all elements with the same name
Click OK and all the cell elements become addrLines. (The document is no longer valid, but we will fix that in a moment.)

We need to remove all the row start and end-tags. You can do this by just selecting them with the mouse and deleting them, of course. Or, more reliably, try putting the cursor on a row tag, and selecting the Document -> XML-Refactoring -> Delete Element Tags command. Remove the table tags in the same way.
Finally wrap the sequence of addrLines that remains in an address and you're almost valid again.
The stamp descriptions have been turned into a list, so we will need to do something very similar to them. Convert all the item elements to stamps using the Rename Element command again
To make the document valid, you just need to wrap the stamps and the address inside a p element, as you did before.

div.p: We leave it to you to complete the tagging of this postcard in the same way as you did the others. You'll need to introduce some div elements at appropriate places, and also transfer some information into the Header. Use the postcards you did before as a model. If you get bored or finish early, try doing one of the other cards as well -- there are three others in the Cards folder, but you'll have to transcribe them yourself.
If you get lost or can't finish don't worry. Our suggested version of the complete set is available for you to look at in the file postcard-archive.xml!

div.head: Using the markup
div.p: The markup introduced you've carefully introduced is not there for its own sake. You can use it to do interesting things with your digital resource. Naturally, since we love reading, we tend to think first of how using the markup to transform the appearance of the resource or parts of it, into something more legible, as a digital document. But it can also can be used to analyse features and structures of the document, to carry out intelligent searching across a large number of resources, or simply to catalogue a collection of documents.

div.head: Transforming for display
div.p:
As you've already seen, Oxygen can transform an XML file for display using Author mode. How about some other transformations? Why not convert the document into HTML or PDF for display on a website? You can try the following on any of the files you prepared yourself, on the file 19701026_004.xml, which contains just one postcard, (but not sadly on the file postcard-archive.xml , for technical reasons)
On the tool bar there is a button with a big red arrow. Click on it (or type CTRL-SHIFT-T, or select Document -> Transformation -> Apply transformation scenario from the menus)
In Oxygen a transformation scenario associates a document with a stylesheet for processing. Some default scenarios are provided for various commonly used formats (notably TEI P5 XHTML , TEI P5 EPUB, TEI P5 PDF, TEI P5 DOCX) and you can also define your own. Select a scenario that looks interesting, and see what happens when you run the transformation, by clicking the Transform now button. Experiment with the others too !

div.head: Searching the structure
div.p: One of the key reasons for introducing markup was that it allows us to access and identify structural components independent of the document in which they appear. For example, we might want a list of just the stamps, or just the dates of posting, for our postcards. We don't have time to explain this in detail, but here are a couple of indications of what's possible, still using Oxygen.

At top left of the Oxygen screen there is a little window labelled XPath 2.0. XPath is a W3C-defined standard language for identifying parts of an XML structure. We won't explain it in full but show what it can do with a few simple examples.

list.item: Open the file postcard-archive.xml in Oxygen. This contains marked up versions of five postcards.

Type //salute into the XPath box and press return. At the bottom of the screen, a table appears containing a row for each occurrence of a salute element anywhere in the document, with first a full description of where it is to be found, and second what it contains. The first line tells is that the text Love Kath. is inside the first salute inside the first div inside the second div of the first body of the first text of the first TEI inside the root TEIcorpus.
Now let's try to find all the titles of our cards. Type //title into the XPath box and press Return.

Hmm, not quite what we wanted. We have the title of the whole collection, the title of the bibliographic source, the title of the card itself... let's try to be more precise. Type //TEI//titleStmt/title instead. This says find any title which is directly contained by a titleStmt which is itself anywhere within a TEI... which is what we wanted. You should see just five lines of results.
How about picking out the stamps? Type //stamp into the box and we will see all the stamp elements.
XPath syntax also allows us to select according to the value of an attribute. Try stamp[@type='postage'] to see just the postage stamps, as opposed to postmarks.
Lastly, how about all the messages?

div.head: Next steps...
div.p: Have we finished our markup now?

Here are just a few ideas for you to consider if you want to continue working with this kind of document:
Like other hand-written materials, postcards can contain errors, additions, corrections, strange spellings, passages which are illegible. The TEI provides markup for all of these.
Postcards typically contain information about real persons and real places at specific times. We should separate out these named entities (as they are called) in our markup by marking them up as names with an appropriate type for example
We could also add markup to explain or normalize the entities being named -- for example, who was Mrs FitzHerbert, and what is the little joke being made here?
In our markup we haven't tried to preserve the original layout or orientation of the writing. Maybe in a very precious or obscure postcard that would be useful too?
There are plenty of other digital resources that reference the entities referred to here: catalogues of postage stamps, gazeteers and maps of placenames, historical biographies, lists of business and publishers, etc. We should be able to link to relevant items in such digital resources.
The postcard itself could have much more metadata added to it : we could add keywords describing the picture, or the means of production, or whatever information we can discover about the size of the original print edition, the present value of the card to collectors, other collections which have copies of it, or the series to which it belongs, and so on...
We could add markup describing the linguistic properties of the writing itself. Postcard messages tend to be informal, but still there are some recurrent motifs and formulae. We could investigate the semiotics of cartophiliac discourse.
... and so on!
